<!-- end of user-specified TAGGED TABLE -->


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On
December&nbsp;31, 2004 and 2003, we had approximately $194&nbsp;million and $160&nbsp;million, respectively, of net deferred tax assets located in countries outside the United
States. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On
December&nbsp;31, 2004, we had $3,258&nbsp;million of loss carryforwards available to reduce future taxable income. Loss carryforwards of $861&nbsp;million must be utilized
within the next five years; $550&nbsp;million must be utilized within the next 10&nbsp;years and the remainder can be utilized over a period greater than 10&nbsp;years. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>NOTE 16: SIGNIFICANT OPERATING AND NONOPERATING ITEMS  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Operating income in 2004 reflected the impact of $480&nbsp;million of expenses primarily related to impairment charges for franchise rights and certain
manufacturing investments. These impairment charges were recorded in the consolidated statement of income line item other operating charges. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
the second quarter of 2004, we recorded impairment charges totaling approximately $88&nbsp;million. These impairments primarily related to the write-downs of certain manufacturing
investments and an intangible asset. As a result of operating losses, management prepared analyses of cash flows expected to result from the use of the assets and their eventual disposition. Because
the sum of the undiscounted cash flows was less than the carrying value of such assets, we recorded an impairment charge to reduce the carrying value of the assets to fair&nbsp;value. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>107</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=3,SEQ=109,EFW="2151637",CP="THE COCA-COLA COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=290953,FOLIO='107',FILE='DISK053:[05ATA5.05ATA1065]EQ1065A.;30',USER='EGAVIRI',CD=';4-MAR-2005;06:46' -->
<A NAME="page_eq1065_1_108"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
the second quarter of 2004, our Company's equity income benefited by approximately $37&nbsp;million for our proportionate share of a favorable tax settlement related to
Coca-Cola FEMSA. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
the third quarter of 2004, we recorded impairment charges of approximately $392&nbsp;million, which were primarily related to the impairment of franchise rights at CCEAG. The CCEAG
impairment was the result of our revised outlook for the German market, which has been unfavorably impacted by volume declines resulting from market shifts related to the deposit law on nonreturnable
beverage packages and the corresponding lack of availability of our products in the discount retail channel. Refer to Note&nbsp;4. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
the fourth quarter of 2004, our Company received a $75&nbsp;million insurance settlement related to the class-action lawsuit that was settled in 2000. Also in the fourth quarter of
2004, the Company donated $75&nbsp;million to the Coca-Cola Foundation. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
the first quarter of 2003, the Company reached a settlement with certain defendants in a vitamin antitrust litigation matter. In that litigation, the Company alleged that certain
vitamin manufacturers participated in a global conspiracy to fix the price of some vitamins, including vitamins used in the manufacture of some of the Company's products. During the first quarter of
2003, the Company received a settlement relating to this litigation of approximately $52&nbsp;million on a pretax basis, or $0.01 per share on an after-tax basis. The amount was recorded
as a reduction to cost of goods sold. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Refer
to Note&nbsp;2 for disclosure regarding the merger of Coca-Cola FEMSA and Panamco in 2003 and the recording of a $102&nbsp;million noncash pretax charge to the
consolidated statement of income line item equity income&#151;net. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
the third quarter of 2002, our Company recorded a noncash pretax charge of approximately $33&nbsp;million related to our share of impairment and restructuring charges taken by
certain equity method investees in Latin America. This charge was recorded in the consolidated statement of income line item equity income&#151;net. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our
Company had direct and indirect ownership interests totaling approximately 18&nbsp;percent in Cervejarias Kaiser S.A. ("Kaiser S.A."). In March&nbsp;2002, Kaiser S.A. sold its
investment in Cervejarias Kaiser Brazil,&nbsp;Ltda to Molson&nbsp;Inc. ("Molson") for cash of approximately $485&nbsp;million and shares of Molson valued at approximately $150&nbsp;million.
Our Company's pretax share of the gain related to this sale was approximately $43&nbsp;million, of which approximately $21&nbsp;million was recorded in the consolidated statement of income line
item equity income&#151;net, and approximately $22&nbsp;million was recorded in the consolidated statement of income line item other income (loss)&#151;net. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
the first quarter of 2002, our Company recorded a noncash pretax charge of approximately $157&nbsp;million (recorded in the consolidated statement of income line item other income
(loss)&#151;net), primarily related to the write-down of certain investments in Latin America. This write-down reduced the carrying value of these investments in Latin
America to fair value. The charge was primarily the result of the economic developments in Argentina during the first quarter of 2002, including the devaluation of the Argentine peso and the severity
of the unfavorable economic outlook. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>NOTE 17: STREAMLINING COSTS  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;During 2003, the Company took steps to streamline and simplify its operations, primarily in North America and Germany. In North America, the Company integrated
the operations of three formerly separate North American business units&#151;Coca-Cola North America, The Minute Maid Company and Coca-Cola Fountain. In Germany, CCEAG took steps to
improve its efficiency in sales, distribution and manufacturing, and our German </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>108</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=4,SEQ=110,EFW="2151637",CP="THE COCA-COLA COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=423029,FOLIO='108',FILE='DISK053:[05ATA5.05ATA1065]EQ1065A.;30',USER='EGAVIRI',CD=';4-MAR-2005;06:46' -->
<A NAME="page_eq1065_1_109"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Division
office also implemented streamlining initiatives. Selected other operations also took steps to streamline their operations to improve overall efficiency and effectiveness. As disclosed in
Note&nbsp;1, under SFAS No.&nbsp;146, a liability is accrued only when certain criteria are met. All of the Company's streamlining initiatives met the criteria of SFAS No.&nbsp;146 as of
December&nbsp;31, 2003, and all related costs have been incurred as of December&nbsp;31, 2003. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Employees
separated from the Company as a result of these streamlining initiatives were offered severance or early retirement packages, as appropriate, which included both financial and
nonfinancial components. The expenses recorded during the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2003 included costs associated with involuntary terminations and other direct costs associated with
implementing these initiatives. As of December&nbsp;31, 2003, approximately 3,700 associates had been separated pursuant to these streamlining initiatives. Other direct costs included the relocation
of employees; contract termination costs; costs associated with the development, communication and administration of these initiatives; and asset write-offs. During 2003, the Company
incurred total pretax expenses related to these streamlining initiatives of approximately $561&nbsp;million, or $0.15 per share after-tax. These expenses were recorded in the line item other
operating charges. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
table below summarizes the costs incurred to date, the balances of accrued streamlining expenses and the movement in those balances as of and for the years ended December&nbsp;31,
2003 and 2004 (in millions): </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>NOTE 18: ACQUISITIONS AND INVESTMENTS  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;During
2004, our Company's acquisition and investment activity totaled approximately $267&nbsp;million, primarily related to the purchase of trademarks, brands and related contractual
rights in Latin America, none of which was individually significant. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;During
2003, our Company's acquisition and investment activity totaled approximately $359&nbsp;million. These acquisitions included purchases of trademarks, brands and related
contractual rights of approximately $142&nbsp;million, none of which was individually significant. Refer to Note&nbsp;4. Other acquisition and investing activity totaled approximately
$217&nbsp;million, and with the exception of the acquisition of Truesdale, none was individually significant. In March&nbsp;2003, our Company acquired a 100&nbsp;percent ownership interest in
Truesdale from CCE for cash consideration of approximately $58&nbsp;million. Truesdale owns a noncarbonated beverage production facility. The purchase price was allocated primarily to property,
plant and equipment acquired. No amount was allocated to intangible assets. Truesdale is included in our North America operating segment. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;During
2002, our Company's acquisition and investment activity totaled approximately $1,144&nbsp;million. Included in this $1,144&nbsp;million, our Company paid $544&nbsp;million
in cash and recorded a note payable of approximately $600&nbsp;million to finance the CCEAG acquisition described below. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
November&nbsp;2001, we entered into the Control and Profit and Loss Transfer Agreement ("CPL") with CCEAG. Under the terms of the CPL, our Company acquired management
control of CCEAG. In November&nbsp;2001, we also entered into a Pooling Agreement with certain shareowners of CCEAG that provided our Company with voting control of CCEAG. Both agreements became
effective in February&nbsp;2002, when our Company acquired control of CCEAG for a term ending no later than December&nbsp;31, 2006. CCEAG is included in our Europe, Eurasia and Middle East
operating segment. As a result of acquiring control of CCEAG, our Company is working to help focus its sales and marketing programs and assist in developing the business. This transaction was
accounted for as a business combination, and the results of CCEAG's operations have been included in the Company's consolidated financial statements since February&nbsp;2002. Prior to
February&nbsp;2002, our Company accounted for CCEAG under the equity method of accounting. As of December&nbsp;31, 2002, our Company had approximately a 41&nbsp;percent ownership interest in the
outstanding shares of CCEAG. In return for control of CCEAG, pursuant to the CPL we guaranteed annual payments, in lieu of dividends by CCEAG, to all other CCEAG shareowners. These guaranteed annual
payments equal 0.76 euro for each CCEAG share outstanding. Additionally, all other CCEAG shareowners entered into either a put or a put/call option agreement with the Company, exercisable at any time
up to the December&nbsp;31, 2006 expiration date. In 2003, one of the other shareowners exercised its put option which represented approximately 29&nbsp;percent of the outstanding </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>110</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=6,SEQ=112,EFW="2151637",CP="THE COCA-COLA COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=430948,FOLIO='110',FILE='DISK053:[05ATA5.05ATA1065]EQ1065A.;30',USER='EGAVIRI',CD=';4-MAR-2005;06:46' -->
<A NAME="page_eq1065_1_111"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>shares
of CCEAG. All payments related to the exercise of the put options will be made in 2006. Our Company entered into either put or put/call agreements for shares representing approximately a
59&nbsp;percent interest in CCEAG. The spread in the strike prices of the put and call options is approximately 3&nbsp;percent. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As
of the date of the transaction, the Company concluded that the exercise of the put and/or call agreements was a virtual certainty based on the minimal differences in the strike
prices. We concluded that either the holder of the put option would require the Company to purchase the shares at the agreed-upon put strike price, or the Company would exercise its call
option and require the shareowner to tender its shares at the agreed-upon call strike price. If these puts or calls are exercised, the actual transfer of shares would not occur until the
end of the term of the CPL. Coupled with the guaranteed payments in lieu of dividends for the term of the CPL, these instruments represented the financing vehicle for the transaction. As such, the
Company determined that the economic substance of the transaction resulted in the acquisition of the remaining outstanding shares of CCEAG and required the Company to account for the transaction as a
business combination. Furthermore, the terms of the CPL transferred control and all of the economic risks and rewards of CCEAG to the Company immediately. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
present value of the total amount likely to be paid by our Company to all other CCEAG shareowners, including the put or put/call payments and the guaranteed annual payments in lieu
of dividends, was approximately $1,041&nbsp;million at December&nbsp;31, 2004. This amount increased from the initial liability of approximately $600&nbsp;million due to the accretion of the
discounted value to the ultimate maturity of the liability, as well as approximately $350&nbsp;million of translation adjustment related to this liability. This liability is
included in the line item other liabilities. The accretion of the discounted value to its ultimate maturity value is recorded in the line item other income (loss)&#151;net, and this amount was
approximately $58&nbsp;million, $51&nbsp;million and $38&nbsp;million, respectively, for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2004, 2003 and 2002. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
July&nbsp;2002, our Company and Danone Waters of North America,&nbsp;Inc. ("DWNA") formed a new limited liability company, CCDA Waters,&nbsp;L.L.C. ("CCDA"), for the production,
marketing and distribution of DWNA's bottled spring and source water business in the United States. In forming CCDA, DWNA contributed assets of its retail bottled spring and source water business in
the United States. These assets included five production facilities, a license for the use of the Dannon and Sparkletts brands, as well as ownership of several value brands. Our Company made a cash
payment to acquire a controlling 51&nbsp;percent equity interest in CCDA and is also providing marketing, distribution and management expertise. This transaction was accounted for as a business
combination, and the consolidated results of CCDA's operations have been included in the Company's consolidated financial statements since July&nbsp;2002. This business combination expanded our
water brands to include a national offering in all sectors of the water category with purified, spring and source waters. CCDA is included in our North America operating segment. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
January&nbsp;2002, our Company and Coca-Cola Bottlers Philippines,&nbsp;Inc. ("CCBPI") finalized the purchase of RFM Corp.'s ("RFM") approximate 83&nbsp;percent interest in
Cosmos Bottling Corporation ("CBC"), a publicly traded Philippine beverage company. CBC is an established carbonated soft-drink business in the Philippines and is included in our Asia
operating segment. The original sale and purchase agreement with RFM was entered into in November&nbsp;2001. As of the date of this sale and purchase agreement, the Company began supplying
concentrate for this operation. The purchase of RFM's interest was finalized on January&nbsp;3, 2002. In March&nbsp;2002, a tender offer was completed with our Company and CCBPI acquiring all
shares of the remaining minority shareowners except for shares representing a 1&nbsp;percent interest in CBC. This transaction was accounted for as a business combination, and the results of CBC's
operations were included in the Company's consolidated financial statements from January&nbsp;2002 to March&nbsp;2003. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>111</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=7,SEQ=113,EFW="2151637",CP="THE COCA-COLA COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=406925,FOLIO='111',FILE='DISK053:[05ATA5.05ATA1065]EQ1065A.;30',USER='EGAVIRI',CD=';4-MAR-2005;06:46' -->
<A NAME="page_eq1065_1_112"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
Company and CCBPI agreed to restructure the ownership of the operations of CBC, and this transaction was completed in April&nbsp;2003. This transaction resulted in the Company
acquiring all the trademarks of CBC, and CCBPI owning approximately 99&nbsp;percent of the outstanding shares of CBC. Accordingly, CBC was deconsolidated by the Company. No gain or loss was recorded
by our Company upon completion of the transaction, as the fair value of the assets exchanged was approximately equal. Additionally, there was no impact on our cash flows related to this transaction. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our
Company acquired controlling interests in CCDA and CBC for a total combined consideration of approximately $328&nbsp;million. As of December&nbsp;31, 2003, the Company allocated
approximately $56&nbsp;million of the purchase price for these acquisitions to goodwill and $208&nbsp;million to other indefinite-lived intangible assets, primarily trademarks, brands and
licenses. This goodwill is all related to the CCDA acquisition and is allocated to our North America operating segment. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
combined 2002 net operating revenues of CCEAG, CBC and CCDA were approximately $1.3&nbsp;billion. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
acquisitions and investments have been accounted for by the purchase method of accounting. Their results have been included in our consolidated financial statements from their
respective dates of acquisition. Assuming the results of these businesses had been included in operations commencing with 2002, pro forma financial data would not be required due to immateriality. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>NOTE 19: OPERATING SEGMENTS  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our Company's operating structure includes the following operating segments: North America; Africa; Asia; Europe, Eurasia and Middle East; Latin America; and
Corporate. North America includes the United States, Canada and Puerto Rico. Prior-period amounts have been reclassified to conform to the current-period presentation. </FONT></P>

<UL>

concentrates and syrups and, in some cases, the sale of finished beverages. The following table summarizes the contribution to net operating revenues from Company operations (in millions): </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I> Method of Determining Segment Profit or Loss  </I></B></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Management evaluates the performance of our operating segments separately to individually monitor the different factors affecting financial performance. Segment
profit or loss includes substantially all the segment's costs of production, distribution and administration. Our Company typically manages and evaluates equity investments and related income on a
segment level. However, we manage certain significant investments, such as our equity interests in CCE, within the Corporate operating segment. Our Company manages income taxes on a global basis. We
manage financial costs, such as interest income and expense, on a global basis within the Corporate operating segment. Thus, we evaluate segment performance based on profit or loss before income taxes
and cumulative effect of accounting change. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>112</FONT></P>

<TD WIDTH="1%"><FONT SIZE=2>%</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD COLSPAN=16><HR NOSHADE SIZE=4></TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<!-- end of user-specified TAGGED TABLE -->


<P><FONT SIZE=2>*&nbsp;&nbsp;Calculation is not meaningful. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>114</FONT></P>

<!-- ZEQ.=2,SEQ=116,EFW="2151637",CP="THE COCA-COLA COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=272578,FOLIO='114',FILE='DISK053:[05ATA5.05ATA1065]ER1065A.;34',USER='SSTANSE',CD=';3-MAR-2005;16:29' -->
<!-- THIS IS THE END OF A COMPOSITION COMPONENT -->

<P><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="page_es1065_1_115"> </A> </FONT> <FONT SIZE=2><B>REPORT OF MANAGEMENT ON INTERNAL CONTROL OVER FINANCIAL REPORTING<BR>  </B></FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>The Coca-Cola Company and Subsidiaries  </I></B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Management of the Company is responsible for the preparation and integrity of the Consolidated Financial Statements appearing in our Annual Report on
Form&nbsp;10-K. The financial statements were prepared in conformity with generally accepted accounting principles appropriate in the circumstances and, accordingly, include certain
amounts based on our best judgments and estimates. Financial information in this Annual Report on Form&nbsp;10-K is consistent with that in the financial statements. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Management
of the Company is responsible for establishing and maintaining adequate internal control over financial reporting as such term is defined in Rules&nbsp;13a-15(f)
under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 ("Exchange Act"). The Company's internal control over financial reporting is designed to provide reasonable assurance regarding the reliability of financial
reporting and the preparation of the Consolidated Financial Statements. Our internal control over financial reporting is supported by a program of internal audits and appropriate reviews by
management, written policies and guidelines, careful selection and training of qualified personnel and a written Code of Business Conduct adopted by our Company's Board of Directors, applicable to all
Company Directors and all officers and employees of our Company and&nbsp;subsidiaries. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Because
of its inherent limitations, internal control over financial reporting may not prevent or detect misstatements and even when determined to be effective, can only provide
reasonable assurance with respect to financial statement preparation and presentation. Also, projections of any evaluation of effectiveness to future periods are subject to the risk that controls may
become inadequate because of changes in conditions, or that the degree of compliance with the policies or procedures may deteriorate. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
Audit Committee of our Company's Board of Directors, composed solely of Directors who are independent in accordance with the requirements of the New York Stock Exchange listing
standards, the Exchange Act and the Company's Corporate Governance Guidelines, meets with the independent auditors, management and internal auditors periodically to discuss internal control over
financial reporting and auditing and financial reporting matters. The Committee reviews with the independent auditors the scope and results of the audit effort. The Committee also meets periodically
with the independent auditors and the chief internal auditor without management present to ensure that the independent auditors and the chief internal auditor have free access to the Committee. Our
Audit Committee's Report can be found in the Company's 2005 proxy statement. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Management
assessed the effectiveness of the Company's internal control over financial reporting as of December&nbsp;31, 2004. In making this assessment, management used the criteria
set forth by the Committee of Sponsoring Organizations of the Treadway Commission (COSO) in </FONT><FONT SIZE=2><I>Internal Control&#151;Integrated Framework</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>. Based on
our assessment, management believes that the Company maintained effective internal control over financial reporting as of December&nbsp;31, 2004. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
Company's independent auditors, Ernst&nbsp;&amp; Young LLP, a registered public accounting firm, are appointed by the Audit Committee of the Company's Board of Directors, subject to
ratification by our Company's shareowners. Ernst&nbsp;&amp; Young LLP have audited and reported on the Consolidated Financial Statements of The Coca-Cola Company and subsidiaries,
management's assessment of the effectiveness of the Company's internal control over financial reporting and the effectiveness of the Company's internal control over financial reporting. The reports of
the independent auditors are contained in this Annual Report. </FONT></P>

<!-- ZEQ.=1,SEQ=117,EFW="2151637",CP="THE COCA-COLA COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=697512,FOLIO='115',FILE='DISK053:[05ATA5.05ATA1065]ES1065A.;25',USER='SSTANSE',CD=';3-MAR-2005;16:49' -->
<A NAME="page_es1065_1_116"> </A>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Report of Independent Registered Public Accounting Firm<BR>
Board of Directors and Shareowners<BR>  </B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>The Coca-Cola Company  </I></B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We have audited the accompanying consolidated balance sheets of The Coca-Cola Company and subsidiaries as of December&nbsp;31, 2004 and 2003, and
the related consolidated statements of income, shareowners' equity, and cash flows for each of the three years in the period ended December&nbsp;31, 2004. Our audits also included the financial
statement schedule listed in the Index at Item 15(a). These financial statements and schedule are the responsibility of the Company's management. Our responsibility is to express an opinion on these
financial statements and schedule based on our audits. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We
conducted our audits in accordance with the standards of the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (United States). Those standards require that we plan and perform the audit to
obtain reasonable assurance about whether the financial statements are free of material misstatement. An audit includes examining, on a test basis, evidence supporting the amounts and disclosures in
the financial statements. An audit also includes assessing the accounting principles used and significant estimates made by management, as well as evaluating the overall financial statement
presentation. We believe that our audits provide a reasonable basis for our opinion. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
our opinion, the financial statements referred to above present fairly, in all material respects, the consolidated financial position of The Coca-Cola Company and
subsidiaries at December&nbsp;31, 2004 and 2003, and the consolidated results of their operations and their cash flows for each of the three years in the period ended December&nbsp;31, 2004, in
conformity with U.S. generally accepted accounting principles. Also, in our opinion, the related financial statement schedule, when considered in relation to the basic financial statements taken as a
whole, presents fairly in all material respects the information set forth therein. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As
discussed in Note&nbsp;1 to the consolidated financial statements, in 2004 the Company adopted the provisions of FASB Interpretation No.&nbsp;46 (revised December 2003) regarding
the consolidation of variable interest
entities. As discussed in Notes&nbsp;1 and 4 to the consolidated financial statements, in 2002 the Company changed its method of accounting for goodwill and other intangible assets. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We
also have audited, in accordance with the standards of the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (United States), the effectiveness of The Coca-Cola Company and
subsidiaries' internal control over financial reporting as of December&nbsp;31, 2004, based on criteria established in </FONT><FONT SIZE=2><I>Internal Control&#151;Integrated
Framework</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2> issued by the Committee of Sponsoring Organizations of the Treadway Commission and our report dated February&nbsp;25, 2005, expressed an unqualified opinion
thereon. </FONT></P>

<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=2,SEQ=118,EFW="2151637",CP="THE COCA-COLA COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=721114,FOLIO='116',FILE='DISK053:[05ATA5.05ATA1065]ES1065A.;25',USER='SSTANSE',CD=';3-MAR-2005;16:49' -->
<A NAME="page_es1065_1_117"> </A>
<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2><B>Report of Independent Registered Public Accounting Firm<BR>
on Internal Control Over Financial Reporting  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Board of Directors and Shareowners<BR>  </B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>The Coca-Cola Company  </I></B></FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We have audited management's assessment, included in the accompanying Report of Management on Internal Control Over Financial Reporting, that The
Coca-Cola Company and subsidiaries maintained effective internal control over financial reporting as of December&nbsp;31, 2004, based on criteria established in </FONT> <FONT SIZE=2><I>Internal Control&#151;Integrated Framework</I></FONT><FONT
SIZE=2> issued by the Committee of Sponsoring Organizations of the Treadway Commission (the COSO criteria).
The Coca-Cola Company's management is responsible for maintaining effective internal control over financial reporting and for its assessment of the effectiveness of internal control over
financial reporting. Our responsibility is to express an opinion on management's assessment and an opinion on the effectiveness of the Company's internal control over financial reporting based on our
audit. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We
conducted our audit in accordance with the standards of the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (United States). Those standards require that we plan and perform the audit to
obtain reasonable assurance about whether effective internal control over financial reporting was maintained in all material respects. Our audit included obtaining an understanding of internal control
over financial reporting, evaluating management's assessment, testing and evaluating the design and operating effectiveness of internal control, and performing such other procedures as we considered
necessary in the circumstances. We believe that our audit provides a reasonable basis for our opinion. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;A
company's internal control over financial reporting is a process designed to provide reasonable assurance regarding the reliability of financial reporting and the preparation of
financial statements for external purposes in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles. A company's internal control over financial reporting includes those policies and procedures
that (1)&nbsp;pertain to the maintenance of records that, in reasonable detail, accurately and fairly reflect the transactions and dispositions of the assets of the company; (2)&nbsp;provide
reasonable assurance that transactions are recorded as necessary to permit preparation of financial statements in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles, and that receipts and
expenditures of the company are being made only in accordance with authorizations of management and directors of the company; and (3)&nbsp;provide reasonable assurance regarding prevention or timely
detection of unauthorized acquisition, use, or disposition of the company's assets that could have a material effect on the financial statements. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Because
of its inherent limitations, internal control over financial reporting may not prevent or detect misstatements. Also, projections of any evaluation of effectiveness to future
periods are subject to the risk that controls may become inadequate because of changes in conditions, or that the degree of compliance with the policies or procedures may deteriorate. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
our opinion, management's assessment that The Coca-Cola Company and subsidiaries maintained effective internal control over financial reporting as of December&nbsp;31,
2004, is fairly stated, in all material respects, based on the COSO criteria. Also, in our opinion, The Coca-Cola Company and subsidiaries maintained, in all material respects, effective
internal control over financial reporting as of December&nbsp;31, 2004, based on the COSO criteria. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We
also have audited, in accordance with the standards of the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (United States), the consolidated balance sheets of The Coca-Cola
Company and subsidiaries as of December&nbsp;31, 2004 and 2003, and the related consolidated statements of income, shareowners' equity, and cash flows for each of the three years in the period ended
December&nbsp;31, 2004, and our report dated February&nbsp;25, 2005, expressed an unqualified opinion thereon. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In the first quarter of 2004 as compared to the first quarter of 2003, the results were impacted by four additional shipping days. The increase in shipping days in the first quarter were
largely offset in the fourth quarter of 2004. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
the second quarter of 2004, our Company's equity income benefited by approximately $37&nbsp;million for our proportionate share of a favorable tax settlement related to
Coca-Cola FEMSA. Refer to Note&nbsp;2. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
the second quarter of 2004, our Company recorded impairment charges totaling approximately $88&nbsp;million primarily related to write-downs of certain manufacturing investments and
an intangible asset. Refer to Note&nbsp;16. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
the second quarter of 2004, our Company recorded approximately $49&nbsp;million of noncash pretax gains on issuances of stock by CCE. Refer to Note&nbsp;3. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
the second quarter of 2004, our Company recorded an income tax benefit of approximately $41&nbsp;million related to the reversal of previously accrued taxes resulting from a
favorable agreement with authorities. Refer to Note&nbsp;15. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
the third quarter of 2004, our Company recorded an income tax benefit of approximately $39&nbsp;million related to the reversal of previously accrued taxes resulting from favorable
resolution of tax matters. Refer to Note&nbsp;15. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
the third quarter of 2004, our Company recorded an income tax expense of approximately $75&nbsp;million related to the recognition of a valuation allowance on certain deferred taxes
of CCEAG. Refer to Note&nbsp;15. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
the third quarter of 2004, our Company recorded impairment charges totaling approximately $392&nbsp;million primarily related to franchise rights at CCEAG. Refer to Note&nbsp;16. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
the fourth quarter of 2004, our Company received a $75&nbsp;million insurance settlement related to the class-action lawsuit that was settled in 2000. Also in the fourth quarter of
2004, the Company donated $75&nbsp;million to the Coca-Cola Foundation. Refer to Note&nbsp;16. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
the fourth quarter of 2004, our Company recorded an income tax benefit of approximately $48&nbsp;million related to the reversal of previously accrued taxes resulting from favorable
resolution of tax matters. Refer to Note&nbsp;15. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
the fourth quarter of 2004, our Company recorded an income tax benefit of approximately $50&nbsp;million related to the realization of certain foreign tax credits per provisions of
the Jobs Creation Act. Refer to Note&nbsp;15. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
the fourth quarter of 2004, our Company recorded approximately $25&nbsp;million of noncash pretax losses to adjust the amount of the gain recognized in the second quarter of 2004 on
issuances of stock by CCE. Refer to Note&nbsp;3. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Certain
amounts previously reported in our 2003 Quarterly Reports on Form&nbsp;10-Q were reclassified to conform to our year-end 2003 presentation. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
the first quarter of 2003, the Company reached a settlement with certain defendants in a vitamin antitrust litigation matter. The Company received a settlement relating to this
litigation of approximately $52&nbsp;million on a pretax basis. Refer to Note&nbsp;16. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
2003, the Company took steps to streamline and simplify its operations, primarily in North America and Germany. Selected other operations also took steps to streamline their
operations to improve overall efficiency and effectiveness. The pretax expense of these streamlining initiatives for the three months ended March&nbsp;31, 2003, June&nbsp;30, 2003,
September&nbsp;30, 2003 and December&nbsp;31, 2003 was $159&nbsp;million, $70&nbsp;million, $43&nbsp;million and $289&nbsp;million, respectively. Refer to Note&nbsp;17. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Effective
May&nbsp;6, 2003, Coca-Cola FEMSA consummated a merger with another of the Company's equity method investees, Panamerican Beverages,&nbsp;Inc. During the third
quarter of 2003, our Company recorded a pretax noncash charge to equity income&#151;net of $95&nbsp;million primarily related to Coca-Cola
FEMSA streamlining initiatives and impairment of certain intangible assets. During the fourth quarter of 2003, our Company recorded a pretax noncash charge of $7&nbsp;million related solely to the
streamlining and integration of these operations. Refer to Note&nbsp;2. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
the fourth quarter of 2003, we favorably resolved various tax matters (approximately $50&nbsp;million), partially offset by additional taxes primarily related to the repatriation of
funds. </FONT></P>

<!-- ZEQ.=1,SEQ=120,EFW="2151637",CP="THE COCA-COLA COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=133403,FOLIO='118',FILE='DISK053:[05ATA5.05ATA1065]EU1065A.;19',USER='SSTANSE',CD=';2-MAR-2005;19:24' -->

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="page_ga1065_1_119"> </A> </FONT></P>

<!-- TOC_END -->
<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="ga1065_glossary"> </A>
<A NAME="toc_ga1065_1"> </A>
<BR></FONT><FONT SIZE=2><B>GLOSSARY    <BR>    </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As used in this report, the following terms have the meanings indicated. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Bottling Partner or Bottler:&nbsp;&nbsp;</B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>businesses that buy concentrates (sometimes referred to as beverage bases) or syrups from the Company, convert
them into finished packaged products and sell them to customers. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Carbonated Soft Drink:&nbsp;&nbsp;</B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>nonalcoholic carbonated beverage (sometimes referred to as soft drinks) containing flavorings and sweeteners.
Excludes, among others, waters and flavored waters, juices and juice drinks, sports drinks, and teas and coffees. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>The Coca-Cola System:&nbsp;&nbsp;</B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>the Company and its bottling partners. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Coca-Cola Trademark Beverages:&nbsp;&nbsp;</B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>cola-flavored Company Trademark Beverages. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Company:&nbsp;&nbsp;</B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>The Coca-Cola Company together with its subsidiaries. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Company Trademark Beverages:&nbsp;&nbsp;</B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>beverages bearing our trademarks and certain other beverage products licensed to our Company or owned by our
bottling partners and distributors, for which our Company provides marketing support and derives profits from the sales. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Concentrate:&nbsp;&nbsp;</B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>material manufactured from Company-defined ingredients and sold to bottlers to prepare finished beverages through the addition
of water and, depending on the product, sweeteners and/or carbonated water marketed under trademarks of the Company. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Consumer:&nbsp;&nbsp;</B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>person who drinks Company products. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Cost of Capital:&nbsp;&nbsp;</B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>after-tax blended cost of equity and borrowed funds used to invest in operating capital required for business. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Customer:&nbsp;&nbsp;</B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>retail outlet, restaurant or other operation that sells or serves Company products directly to&nbsp;consumers. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Derivatives:&nbsp;&nbsp;</B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>contracts or agreements, the value of which may change based on changes in interest rates, exchange rates, prices of
securities, or financial or commodity indices. The Company uses derivatives to reduce our exposure to adverse fluctuations in interest and exchange rates and other market risks. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Fountain:&nbsp;&nbsp;</B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>system used by retail outlets to dispense product into cups or glasses for immediate consumption. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Gallons:&nbsp;&nbsp;</B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>unit of measurement for concentrates, syrups, beverage bases, finished beverages and powders (in all cases, expressed in
equivalent gallons of syrup) for all beverage products which are reportable as unit case volume. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Gross Profit Margin:&nbsp;&nbsp;</B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>gross profit divided by net operating revenues. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Market:&nbsp;&nbsp;</B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>when used in reference to geographic areas, territory in which the Company and its bottling partners do business, often defined by
national boundaries. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Net Capital:&nbsp;&nbsp;</B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>shareowners' equity added to net debt. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Net Debt:&nbsp;&nbsp;</B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>total debt less the sum of cash, cash equivalents and current marketable securities. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Noncarbonated Beverages:&nbsp;&nbsp;</B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>nonalcoholic beverages without carbonation including, but not limited to, waters and flavored waters, juices and
juice drinks, sports drinks, and teas and coffees. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Operating Margin:&nbsp;&nbsp;</B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>operating income divided by net operating revenues. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Per Capita Consumption:&nbsp;&nbsp;</B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>average number of servings consumed per person, per year in a specific market. Per capita consumption of Company
beverage products is calculated by multiplying our unit case volume by 24, and dividing by the population. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>119</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=1,SEQ=121,EFW="2151637",CP="THE COCA-COLA COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=415680,FOLIO='119',FILE='DISK053:[05ATA5.05ATA1065]GA1065A.;24',USER='EGAVIRI',CD=';4-MAR-2005;06:45' -->
<A NAME="page_ga1065_1_120"> </A>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Return on Average Total Capital:&nbsp;&nbsp;</B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>net income before cumulative effect of accounting change (adding back interest expense, net of related
taxes) divided by average total capital. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Return on Average Shareowners' Equity:&nbsp;&nbsp;</B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>net income before cumulative effect of accounting change divided by average shareowners' equity. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Serving:&nbsp;&nbsp;</B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>eight U.S. fluid ounces of a finished beverage. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Syrup:&nbsp;&nbsp;</B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>concentrate mixed with sweetener and water, sold to bottlers and customers who add carbonated water to produce finished carbonated
soft drinks. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Total Capital:&nbsp;&nbsp;</B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>shareowners' equity plus total debt. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Total Debt:&nbsp;&nbsp;</B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>loans and notes payable, current maturities of long-term debt and long-term debt. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Total Market Value of Common Stock:&nbsp;&nbsp;</B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>stock price as of a date multiplied by the number of shares outstanding as of the same date. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Unit Case:&nbsp;&nbsp;</B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>unit of measurement equal to 192 U.S. fluid ounces of finished beverage (24 eight-ounce servings). </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Unit Case Volume, or Volume:&nbsp;&nbsp;</B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>the number of unit cases (or unit case equivalents) of Company trademark or licensed beverage products
directly or indirectly sold by the Coca-Cola system to customers. Volume primarily consists of beverage products bearing Company trademarks. Also included in volume are certain beverage
products licensed to our Company or owned by our bottling partners and distributors, for which our Company provides marketing support and derives income from the sales. Such beverage products licensed
to our Company or owned by our bottling partners account for a minimal portion of total unit case volume. Unit case volume is derived based on estimates received by the Company from its bottling
partners and distributors. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>120</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>

<A NAME="toc_gc1065_1"> </A>
<BR></FONT><FONT SIZE=2><B>ITEM 9. CHANGES IN AND DISAGREEMENTS WITH ACCOUNTANTS ON ACCOUNTING AND FINANCIAL DISCLOSURE    <BR>    </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Not applicable. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="gc1065_item_9a._controls_and_procedures"> </A>
<A NAME="toc_gc1065_2"> </A>
<BR></FONT><FONT SIZE=2><B>ITEM 9A. CONTROLS AND PROCEDURES    <BR>    </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company, under the supervision and with the participation of its management, including the Chief Executive Officer and the Chief Financial Officer, evaluated
the effectiveness of the design and operation of the Company's "disclosure controls and procedures" (as defined in Rule&nbsp;13a-15(e) under the Securities Exchange Act) as of the end of
the period covered by this report. Based on that evaluation, the Chief Executive Officer and the Chief Financial Officer concluded that the Company's disclosure controls and procedures are effective
in timely making known to them material information relating to the Company and the Company's consolidated subsidiaries required to be disclosed in the Company's reports filed or submitted under the
Exchange Act. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
report called for by Item 308(a) of Regulation&nbsp;S-K is incorporated herein by reference to Report of Management on Internal Control Over Financial Reporting,
included in Part&nbsp;II, Item 8 of this report. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
attestation report called for by Item 308(b) of Regulation&nbsp;S-K is incorporated herein by reference to Report of Independent Registered Public Accounting Firm on
Internal Control Over Financial Reporting, included in Part&nbsp;II, Item&nbsp;8 of this report. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;There
has been no change in the Company's internal control over financial reporting during the quarter ended December&nbsp;31, 2004 that has materially affected, or is reasonably
likely to materially affect, the Company's internal control over financial reporting. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="gc1065_item_9b._other_information"> </A>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Not applicable. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="ge1065_part_iii"> </A>
<A NAME="toc_ge1065_1"> </A>
<BR></FONT><FONT SIZE=2><B>PART III    <BR>    </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="ge1065_item_10._directors_and___ge102281"> </A>
<A NAME="toc_ge1065_2"> </A></FONT> <FONT SIZE=2><B>ITEM 10. DIRECTORS AND EXECUTIVE OFFICERS OF THE REGISTRANT    <BR>    </B></FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The information under the headings "Board of Directors," "Section&nbsp;16(a) Beneficial Ownership Reporting Compliance," "Information About the Board of
Directors and Corporate Governance&#151;The Audit Committee" and "Information About the Board of Directors and Corporate Governance&#151;The Board and Board Committees" in the Company's
2005 Proxy Statement is incorporated herein by reference. See Item X in Part&nbsp;I of this report for information regarding executive officers of the Company. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
Company has adopted a code of business conduct and ethics applicable to the Company's Directors, officers (including the Company's principal executive officer, principal financial
officer and controller) and employees, known as the Code of Business Conduct. The Code of Business Conduct is available on the Company's website. In the event that we amend or waive any of the
provisions of the Code of Business Conduct applicable to our principal executive officer, principal financial officer or controller, we intend to disclose the same on the Company's website at
www.coca-cola.com. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On
May 13, 2004, we filed with the New York Stock Exchange ("NYSE") the Annual CEO Certification regarding the Company's compliance with the NYSE's Corporate Governance listing standards
as required by Section&nbsp;303A-12(a) of the NYSE Listed Company Manual. In addition, the Company has filed as exhibits to this annual report and to the annual report on Form&nbsp;10-K for the
year ended December&nbsp;31, 2003, the applicable certifications of its Chief Executive Officer and its Chief Financial Officer required under Section&nbsp;302 of the Sarbanes-Oxley Act of 2002,
regarding the quality of the Company's public disclosures. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="ge1065_item_11._executive_compensation"> </A>
<A NAME="toc_ge1065_3"> </A>
<BR></FONT><FONT SIZE=2><B>ITEM 11. EXECUTIVE COMPENSATION    <BR>    </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The information under the headings "Information About the Board of Directors and Corporate Governance&#151;Director Compensation," and "Compensation
Committee Interlocks and Insider Participation" and under the principal heading "EXECUTIVE COMPENSATION" in the Company's 2005 Proxy Statement is incorporated herein by reference. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="ge1065_item_12._security_ownership_of__ite04004"> </A>
<A NAME="toc_ge1065_4"> </A>
<BR></FONT><FONT SIZE=2><B>ITEM 12. SECURITY OWNERSHIP OF CERTAIN BENEFICIAL OWNERS AND MANAGEMENT AND RELATED STOCKHOLDER MATTERS    <BR>    </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The information under the headings "Equity Compensation Plan Information," "Ownership of Equity Securities in the Company," "Principal Shareowners" and "Ownership
of Securities in Investee Companies" in the Company's 2005 Proxy Statement is incorporated herein by reference. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="ge1065_item_13._certain_relati__ge102124"> </A>
<A NAME="toc_ge1065_5"> </A>

reference. </FONT></P>

<FONT SIZE=2><I><A HREF="#toc_de1065_1">PART I</A></I></FONT><BR>
<UL>
<FONT SIZE=2><I><A HREF="#toc_de1065_2">ITEM 1. BUSINESS</A></I></FONT><BR>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="kk1083_amendment_number_three_to_the___ame03009"> </A>
<A NAME="toc_kk1083_1"> </A>
<BR></FONT><FONT SIZE=2><B>AMENDMENT NUMBER THREE TO<BR>  THE EXECUTIVE MEDICAL PLAN OF<BR>  THE COCA-COLA COMPANY    <BR>    </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;THIS AMENDMENT to the Executive Medical Plan of The Coca-Cola Company (the "Plan") is adopted by the Plan Administrator. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2><B>W I T N E S S E T H:  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;WHEREAS, Section&nbsp;10 of the Plan provides that the Plan Administrator may amend the Plan at any time; and </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;WHEREAS,
the Plan Administrator wishes to amend the Plan. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;NOW,
THEREFORE, the Plan Administrator hereby amends the Plan as follows: </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Effective
January&nbsp;1, 2005, Section&nbsp;12.4 shall be restated in its entirety as follows: </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;"12.4&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<U>Establishment
and Maintenance of Adequate Separation between the Company and the Plan</U>. In accordance with the requirements of HIPAA, only
the following employees/classes of employees will be given access to PHI to be disclosed: </FONT></P>
</UL>
<!-- User-specified TAGGED TABLE -->

<P ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=2><B>EXHIBIT 10.11.5  </B></FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="ko1083_amendment_four_to_the_suppleme__ame03529"> </A>
<A NAME="toc_ko1083_1"> </A>
<BR></FONT><FONT SIZE=2><B>AMENDMENT FOUR TO THE SUPPLEMENTAL BENEFIT PLAN<BR>  AS AMENDED AND RESTATED EFFECTIVE JANUARY 1, 2002    <BR>    </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;THIS AMENDMENT to The Coca-Cola Company Supplemental Benefit Plan (the "Plan") is adopted by The Coca-Cola Company Benefits Committee (the
"Committee"). </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2><B>W I T N E S S E T H:  </B></FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;WHEREAS, Section&nbsp;6.4 of the Plan provides that the Committee may amend the Plan at any time; </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;WHEREAS,
the Committee wishes to amend the Plan to add a participating subsidiary; </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;NOW,
THEREFORE, the Committee hereby amends the Plan as follows: </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Effective
January&nbsp;1, 2005, Appendix&nbsp;A is hereby amended to add an additional Participating Subsidiary as follows: </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>Coca-Cola
Properties, LLC, effective January&nbsp;1, 2005 </FONT></P>

</UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;IN
WITNESS WHEREOF, the Committee has adopted this Amendment Four on the date shown below, but effective as of the dates indicated above. </FONT></P>

<TYPE>EX-10.41
<SEQUENCE>4
<FILENAME>a2151637zex-10_41.htm
<DESCRIPTION>EXHIBIT 10.41
<TEXT>
<HTML>
<HEAD>
</HEAD>
<BODY BGCOLOR="#FFFFFF" LINK=BLUE  VLINK=PURPLE>
<BR>
<FONT SIZE=3 ><A HREF="#05ATA1065_4">QuickLinks</A></FONT>
<font size=3> -- Click here to rapidly navigate through this document</font>
<P ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=2><B>EXHIBIT 10.41  </B></FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2><B>LETTERHEAD OF THE COCA-COLA COMPANY  </B></FONT></P>

<!-- User-specified TAGGED TABLE -->
<TABLE WIDTH="100%" BORDER=0 CELLSPACING=0 CELLPADDING=0>
<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD WIDTH="40%" ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>Cynthia McCague<BR>
Senior Vice President, Human Resources</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="36%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="24%" ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>Address Reply To<BR>
P.O.&nbsp;Box 1734 NAT 2413<BR>
Atlanta, Georgia 30301<BR>
404-676-3131<BR>
Fax: 404-598-3131</FONT></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<!-- end of user-specified TAGGED TABLE -->


<P><FONT SIZE=2>October&nbsp;7,
2004 </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Mr.&nbsp;Daniel
Palumbo<BR>
The Coca-Cola Company<BR>
Atlanta, Georgia 30301 </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Dear
Dan: </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Thank
you for being willing to discuss the terms of your separation. The following are the agreed terms of the separation agreement: </FONT></P>

<UL>
<DL compact>
<DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>1.</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>You
will resign as Senior Vice President of The Coca-Cola Company and as Chief Marketing Officer, effective immediately. You will remain an employee of the Company at your
current salary until October&nbsp;31, 2004 (the "Separation Date") to transition your work.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>2.</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>When
you sign the enclosed release, you will be eligible for payments under the Company's Severance Pay Plan equivalent to two years of salary. You may elect to take these payments in
either serial payments or in a lump sum. Your decision as to the type of payments will affect benefits, such as health and life insurance. If you elect serial payments, the payments will begin after
October&nbsp;31, 2004.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>3.</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>Your
retirement benefits will consist only of those benefits vested as of your Separation Date under the normal terms of the applicable plans. As soon as reasonably practical after
your Separation Date, you will receive a lump sum distribution of your Supplemental Thrift account according to the terms of the applicable plan.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>4.</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>As
of your separation date of October&nbsp;31, 2004, you will be fully vested in 16,000 stock options at a strike price of $43.215/share. You will be able to hold these options and
exercise them for a twenty-four month period, provided you elect serial severance. This is consistent with the terms of the stock option agreement and plan. The remaining unvested options
as of the Separation Date will be forfeited. When you exercise your vested stock options, you will be personally responsible for paying any taxes owed on such exercises.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>5.</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>You
will not be required to repay any portion of the hiring bonus paid to you.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>6.</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>The
Company will pay you $50,000 for out-placement services.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>7.</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>The
Company will pay you $25,000 for unused temporary living allocation and school tuition fees.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>8.</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>The
Company will continue to indemnify you for legal fees related to your position as an officer of the Company, pursuant to the Company Bylaws unless and until otherwise notified.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>9.</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>You
will not be eligible for a bonus for 2004.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>10.</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>You
will forfeit any payments under the Company's long-term incentive plans currently in progress.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>11.</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>All
restricted stock awards will be forfeited on the Separation Date.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>12.</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>You
will receive payment for any vacation not used this year. </FONT></DD></DL>
</UL>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=1,SEQ=1,EFW="2151637",CP="THE COCA-COLA COMPANY",DN="4",CHK=656390,FOLIO='blank',FILE='DISK020:[05ATA3.05ATA1083]KT1083A.;2',USER='SSTANSE',CD=';3-MAR-2005;16:57' -->
<UL>

<DL compact>
<DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>13.</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>The
terms and conditions in this letter are further conditioned upon your signing and adhering to the attached Full and Complete Release and Agreement on Confidentiality and
Competition, and will be subject to the approval of the Compensation Committee. </FONT></DD></DL>
</UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Dan,
thank you for the time you have spent transitioning your role and the Marketing organization. Please feel free to give me a call if you have any questions or would like more information regarding
the above. </FONT></P>
